posts.name: Anonymous
posts.sub: Is she into me at all?
posts.com:
I (26 year old male) met a young woman (20 years) by chance, through common relatives. We shared a common interest in art and indoors activities, so we exchanged numbers. She was texting me almost daily, until we met at an art gallery. The date went to well that she was the one to request a follow-up. And then I suggested a third, gradually dazzled by her myself. And yesterday, we had a fourth.

Psychologically, we have flawless chemistry, I can say so without overestimation. We are both fairly lonely people, bookish and withdrawn, yet we talked for hours and hours and hours to no end and never felt uncomfortable. We talk about art, science, architecture, history, but also just deeply personal and random stuff. I don't believe many second dates go so well you can just stroll around the city for hours, talk and never feel bored. She visits the places I suggest, watches series I have mentioned to her, agrees to long dates very readily, so she is ready to be led by me into activities as well.

Physically, I am not sure what to make of our interactions. They are ... weird and send very mixed signals. During the first two dates, we simply hugged in a non-suggestive fashion, when we met and when we parted. I thought little of it, albeit I noticed our hugging felt somewhat robotic. I hugged - she hugged back in the exact same fashion. I let go - she let go. But we just met and she is very withdrawn in all her mannerisms, so I did not expect much anyways. Every woman has her own treshold for when she is ready to get physical: for some it's the first date, for some the 100st. I liked her so much I was willing to go on 200 without touching.

CONTINUED BELOW

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
During the third and fourth dates, we began to touch more often, closely and that's when I began to question whether our dates were dates at all. Whether she is capable of sexuality at all, which is why I am here.

As our hugs became more frequent, I asked her at one point openly whether she enjoys the gesture, as she never initiated it: "I definitely enjoy the tactile sensation", she said. What a weird way to describe it, I thought. Even later: "I feel bad about enjoying hugs. It makes me feel like a primitive animal". Again, I had no idea what to make of this commentary. I must note, however, that gradually she began to continue hugging me even after I let her go sometimes - signalling she's definitely not against hugging, just not nearly as eager to the point of initiating.

At one point when walking through crowds, I took her hand. She definitely readily accepted the gesture, without hesitation, and held mine back. (I even checked: sometimes, I let go, which would have resulted in our hands parting, if she didn't hold mine as well. She still held my hand.) Many women consider holding hands in a crowd a quite intimate gesture reserved for a partner, as it implies to the world "we are together, I am his woman". I am not certain whether she saw it that way.

We went to a cinema, where she felt cold. I gave her my wool sweater, which obviously collected a bit of my sweat and body odor over the day. She pressed the sweater against herself for warmth. (You do not hug with the smelly sweater of a guy who repulses you on some level, do you?) I also rubbed her hands and arms a bit for warmth. Again, a gesture she accepted readily. I briefly touched her thigh once. No reaction whatsoever, neither enthusiasm nor discomfort.

While never outright enthusiastic about our touches, never initiating (except touching my hand sometimes), she never rejected them, either. She seemed so ... perfectly neutral about it all.

CONTINUED BELOW

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
At one point I asked her, half-jokingly, whether she is into men (literally: whether she desires them). She answered, in her typical very rational and intellectual fashion: "I find them interesting, to collect information about them. Otherwise, no idea what you want to hear." She also told me she self-diagnozed with Schizoid Personality Disorder online.

But the probably weirdest thing happened when we parted for the last time. I thought about kissing her for a parting, ultimately deciding against. I was just so unsure what to make of our touches so far and would only go for something definitely sexual if I am 100% certain it's reciprocated, which I wasn't.

Well, start with what we know women find attractive that can be worked on. In modern redpill it's called Money Muscles Game Frame, but there's nuance to all of it
>money
Literal money, achievement, or projecting a strong ambition to achieve. The goal doesn't have to yield financial results,
but it does have to be important. Often just having the big dreams can be as good as achieving the dream, especially if you're young. Never talk small about your goals ever again, "oh, i just want a good job that let's me focus on hobbies..." UGLY. Broke artists and wannabe rappers pull mad bitches and always have because of their high ambition/passion for their art despite having no success at all.
>muscles
Muscular physique, but also athletic body in motion. I love lifting and
suggest it, but it just doesn't fire neurons in a girl like jumping, climbing, throwing, hitting, unless you're moving elite amounts of weight. Do both.
>game
The social element. Social ease, unafraid socially, good grooming and planned outfits, gaining public recognition/status, being a leader within whatever group you fall into, and "gaming" cognitive triggers to appear attractive.
>frame
The mental element. Belief in your own worth, unphaseable by things a woman says, understanding and passing her shit tests (tests of your value as a mate), and remaining the master of your own life, in which a girl is just a cherry on top of your cake of a life.

Game and frame is what anons seem to struggle with the most. Game has many books written on it, Models is in the resources of OP and its a popular one bc of it's lack of "gamey" tactics. Otherwise, make going out and meeting lots of people guys and girls a priority in your life. Your PC and consoles are the enemy.

My point is this: Let go of projecting this trope onto people and you will see clearer and find more decent women. Don’t settle for degenerate whores—but don’t expect perfection either; it doesn’t exist.

posts.sub: How to deal with broken trust before marriage
posts.com:
So here's the thing, I used to trust my fiancé to death. If someone had told me he had lied to me, I would have never believed it. We started out having a long-distance relationship and then we met, and right after corona we moved in together.

We have a set date to get married and we have 80% of preparations ready. But a couple of months ago, a friend of his told me he had been flirting and going out with another woman when he was in his country. I didn't believe it until I saw actual proof. I was devastated, we talked it out and he promised there were no more secrets. We worked on our communication and trust and it was going well.

But now, a bunch of months after we started planning out the wedding, I've been told he actually went on several dates with this woman, lied a lot to me about what he was doing at the time and actually slept together the day before he moved in with me.

I feel dumb as hell. It's in the past, so should I just talk it out and forgive him, build trust back and move on?
Problem is, even if he won't do it again he's proved he's capable of doing it and he's perfectly fine lying to me. So I don't know if I'm dumb for even considering working on this.

Am I being gaslighted into believing this has no importance because it's in the past? Does it make sense breaking up a relationship that has been working perfectly for a while now?

Am I a retard for considering this has been working when he has cheated on me?

posts.sub: Too many Coincidences of encountering same Word in Different Places
posts.com:
First I am not schizophrenic in anyway and have a solid materialistic perception of the world so no stale schizo jokes pls.
The problem is, I just keep seeing the exact same word immediately in two entirely different medias. Examples: the last word on the (paper) book I was reading and the first word I noticed on my computer screen. The word I just said to myself and the first word I randomly saw in my dictionary. Once when I was thinking about what to say and the other person suddenly misspoke and said the exact same word I was thinking, and it wasn't even related to what he was talking about. This happened too many times that I feel less and less inclined to brush it off as "coincidence". So why am I noticing these things?

>inb4 we live in le thtimulathion
That is laughable because if this is a stimulation which IS the world itself, then nothing is changed, the world is still the world, you are just using another word to describe it.
I do remember reading somebody on this basement dwelling skinhead forum describing similar experiences. What caused this? Why am I noticing this? I still refuse to believe it's anything supernatural. Please explain to me with psychology or sciences. Thank you.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: *simulation

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28081961
It is called "Blue [or green or red] Car Syndrome"

You never pay much attention to cars going by, and then you buy a blue car, and suddenly you see blue cars everywhere. There are no more of them than ever before - you are just attuned to noticing them when you didn't before.

Every day you encounter thousands of words. Inevitably coincidences of the sort you mention will arise, and you won't even notice them. But once you start looking for them, you will spot them. There are no more than ever before.

>>28078949
Another good concept to understand is living in the moment. When you go out to bars/clubs, you can't be looking for girls TOO MUCH. What I mean is you can't just expect your 10/10 dream girl to just come up out of nowhere. You got to realize it may not happen tonight, but you should still have a good time. Another incel problem is that they obsess either about the woman they WILL have or the ones they COULD'VE had years ago. Living in the moment and realizing "I don't have a girl, what can I do NOW to fix it?" is the first step to curing inceldom. Looksmaxing may help, but you cannot just use it as a means to an end. Like an addict, you have to truly want to change to do so. Stop being antisocial and start talking to people, little by little. The bus driver, the cashier, people you see around. Specially older people since they're more friendly and less likely to be staring at their phones. From there you become more confident and able to speak up for yourself, and you feel less like repressing who you are inside. That doesn't mean you should start ranting about the nogs to people, but just chatting about common interests, movies etc. Then the idea of approaching a women who makes you feel all tingly feels MUCH less intimidating, trust me on this one. And just be a cool and confident version of your self.

It's about being a whole person, essentially. Try to get in contact with your family regularly, assuming they're not peices of shit. Watch the sunrise. Get some pets, if you can. If you're stuck in a dead-end job, make the best of it. That's simply what life is about, my friend.

>>28080948

Not that anon, and I'm not in full agreement that everything is going to go to shit but the gist of it:

In the US, the federal government has been debt spending itself silly for decades. The economy dodged the inflationary impact from this by 1) maintaining interest rates at declining and eventually near 0 levels since the early 80s; 2) most governments and large corporations around the world have used the US dollar to conduct trade and settled contracts thus a lot of dollars have sat around internationally as opposed to being in the domestic economy.

The Russia/Ukraine war and importantly the resulting seizing of Russian assets denominated in USD has made more countries leery of holding cash reserves of USD and have even been attempting to get them off the books, thus slowly forcing them back into the US economy.

To deal with the inflationary pressure, the Federal Reserve must now raise interest rates to pull liquidity out of the domestic economy because hyperinflation tends to destroy governments historically. Instead, many large businesses have been living severely overleveraged for decades, because they could. In a declining interest rate environment you can rollover debt to a lower and lower interest rate and just be able to keep maintaining the house of cards.

But the Fed is now staring down the barrel of crashing the economy (killing off all these zombie corporations in the process) or risking a hyperinflationary crisis that ends the US federal government. So obviously, they're in the midst of crashing the economy to try and save their own asses.

Might it go apocalyptic? Sure, it's possible. And if you're overleveraged, you're gonna get it in the ass no doubt. But it's definitely going to be rough no matter who you are.

posts.com:
>>28078935
No need for books anymore OP. And if you need to read a book and write shit about it, just look up a summary and write a bunch of analytical academic jargon about it. I BSed my way through the entirety of undergrad while doing >>28079120. Here's some stuff I used/did to do it:

1. Chegg
If you don't use it often/are just looking up already existing answers to problemsets you can find people on Reddit who will screenshot answers and send them to you

2. Various calculator apps
https://www.mathway.com/
https://www.wolframalpha.com/
https://www.integral-calculator.com/
https://www.derivative-calculator.net/
https://www.symbolab.com/
There's more but you can find them yourself.

3. Get diagnosed with mental health issue/bullshit your professors
Say you're having family issues or death of a pet or someone you know which is causing lots of distress, shit like this can actually get you some leniency on turning in assignments late (worked better for me during pandemic and online courses). You probably have autism so I doubt this would be too difficult

4. Know which classes you can skip
If attendance is graded, you basically have to go. Usually, there are some "free" days you can miss, so plan out which days you will intentionally miss (usually sometime in middle of semester). You will learn which classes you can skip and which classes you should attend very early on.

5. Copying shit
If you are going to plagiarize don't just copy paste shit, or just change a few words. Rewrite it completely but express the exact same thing. You can run your text through a plagiarism checker like Turnitin so you can be sure that nothing will be detected.

There's also ChatGPT but I graduated before that shit came out. If you can't make it through undergrad using this guide you're either too retarded, too autistic, or should switch majors to something easier.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
First thing to understand is this. You don't love any historical figures. You might be obsessed with an historical figure, you might fantasize about a historical figure, you might idealise a historical figure, you may be infatuated with the idea of a historical figure, enjoy their works or their historical actions. But love, no.

Love is something that can ONLY exist after spending a significant amount of in person time with someone else, building shared experience, seeing their quirks, bonding, etc.

The next thing you have to understand is that you obsess over a historical figure for the same reasons people get into online only long distance relationships. Because it's safer than being vulnerable with someone in real life. See, the way things are the person you've made up in your head holds no actual real connection to the historical figure. Instead because there's so many gaps in how they behaved day to day, how they'd react to various situations, how they smelt or talked or whatever, it all gives you opportunities to replace them in your mind with a fantasy.

Your ideal person. In short you don't love them, you love yourself or at least the fictional version of them you made up. It means they can never let you down, never cheat, never fail you, never risk anything. You can just wallow in fantasy loosely tied to someone who once lived. And perhaps the big selling point, they leave your mind whenever you don't want to think about them.

A real life person is none of those things. Real life people are imperfect, with imperfect behaviour and unexpected and sometimes undesirable reactions, quirks and behaviours that may leave you wanting. That aren't ideal. Real relationships have demands, they don't just go away when you cbf, they may let you down, cheat or fail you. So you retreat to fantasy, but acknowledge at least on some level how unfulfilling and unhealthy that is.

You're having a love affair with yourself. Seek therapy to deal with your issues.

Sounds like a genuine, if confused woman, just trying to get her life together. I think she likes you, and is being honest with what she says, however this raises the problem of why. The answer is probably the above; she doesn't know where her life is heading and she's reluctant about letting a relationship with a new guy define all her long-term plans. I reckon there's probably more stuff going on in her life, or stuff that has happened to her in the past, that has made her hesitant to commit to anything new that comes into her life, and she probably has a number of ideas about where she should/ would like to take her life going forward. If I'm right about my assessment, she'll probably change her mind about you if you conduct yourself in an honest, forthright manner, and just keep trying to be yourself. That said, if she asks for space she will probably not take it well if you refuse. Women at that age are more mindful about their boundaries.

Now if things continue like this for an extended period of time with no signs of changing, or you ever get the impression that she is being dishonest and perhaps trying to use you for something, then you should raise the issue with her, and if she remains obstinate or freaks out, then either she is trying to use you as a placeholder while she waits for a better man, or she is simply too confused and uncertain about what she wants in order for her to give you what you need in a relationship long-term. In either case, you should cut your losses, and pursue love elsewhere.

In the meantime, just maintain your affection and keep some distance, and little by little, she should lower her walls back down again.

Realize that ultimately all of their and your talents and tangible possessions will one day no longer exist and appreciate what you have right now

Do what you enjoy, get good at it, and when it bores you, do something else. Work so you can eat, drink, and sleep without fear of lacking shelter, but strive to make a living by not working.

Comparing yourself to the 7,000,000,000 other people on earth is simply not fair, so stop looking at social media. Many people are in the same situation, and most are worse off.
Read books, meditate, and write about yourself. What is truly motivating you? What do you want? And what do you truly need?

As much as I don't like this approach, here's what I'd say :

Don't put yourself in settings where he can make an explicit move on you. If he does and you have to reject him to keep your game going, chances are you will lose him.

So look for public and chaste places, then you can flirt with him a little, ambiguous stuff. Maybe just look at him for a little too long or too often, get closer to him physically (without touching, or very rarely), maybe show a little interest in his life / hobbies / ideas / whatever.

But watch out for serious plans he can ask you. Like asking you for a private date with him. If you want to keep the game going, try to push it further in the future, this way you're not rejecting him, only delaying him and the risk of him losing interest is not as strong (but still there).

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Neither. You choose a major based strictly on these factors

(1) Job availability/demand in the places you want to live both now and predicted into the future. Think about the next 30 years.

(2) Pay range both at entry level and over time. How long promotions to a decent salary will realistically take and what it will require to get there

(3) Working conditions and work/life balance

(4) Your natural inclination to succeed at the tasks necessary under not just the goal roal but all the stages in the org chart leading up to it.

That's it. That's all you consider. All of this "find your passion" bullshit from millennials has people lost, industries congested, others with skills shortages, people feeling empty and flip flopping industries every 5 minutes. It's complete and utter bullshit.

Passion is fleeting, it's ok for hobbies but not for work. Work is not life, work is the thing you do in order to afford life whether you feel like doing it or not. That's why it's called a work/life balance, because you're balancing work with your actual life.

You will inevitably resent work sometimes, because you are forced to do it at step times, on step days, regardless of how you feel about it. That's what work is. You find things to enjoy (not love) about work AFTER you've been hired, that part is all attitude.

Who you are, that doesn't play any role in this. Not who you are today, not who you hope and dream of becoming. Just the 4 factors I listed.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28071755
It depends on where you live.
If you're over seas, and English is your second language, stick to learning English, that'll help you get around everywhere else, because many foreigners who travel know both English and their own Native Language already, so it's easily the most useful language to know today.

If English is your first Language, however, then you're in a situation where you've already mastered the most complex language used today.

That means, every other language out there, will be a lot easier to pick up.

If you want to learn a language that is similar to English, I would recommend a romantic language, such as:
>Spanish
>Latin
>French
>Italian
>Portuguese
>Welsh
>Gaelic
All of these carry similar sentence structures, the way you speak these languages is not far off from how you speak English. German is also.

There's also a wide range of Eastern European Languages, such as Russian, Romanian, Bulgarian, Turkish, Hungarian, Slavic, all have a learning curve of their own, and are only used in their home countries. Norwegian, Swedish, and Finnish tongues are also exclusive to their Country.

Then, there's arabic, which is a challenge all on it's own, and Hindi is a complicated language, but nonetheless, very beautiful.

As for Far Eastern Languages, there's an emphasis on syllables. Chinese, whether simplified or Traditional Mandarin, is a symbol oriented language, as is Taiwanese, Vietnamese, Thai, Malaysian, Indonesian, Mongolian, and Samoan, and other pacific islander languages(Hawaiian put aside, that's it's own can of worms, much easier to learn than the other languages listed here, and the most fun). Japanese and Korean, are a little more sophisticated with their vocabulary and tradition, but is resemblant of mandarin.

If I had to give you a "best" language, I'd give you two:

>Best Main Language: English
>Best Recreational Second Language or Non-English Language: Hawaiian.

Mate, you can think of it in whatever way gets you through the day, but the medical reality is that autism is a genetic, neurodevelopmental disorder where the patient never develops beyond a set age in childhood. Where that set age is varies between individuals, it can range anywhere from infancy through to mid teens. Where mental age stops dictates the level of social awareness, social skills and communication skills developed.

As a genetic disorder, it is passed on by genetically damaged parents. Ie. If you're autistic, your parents are genetically weak and should never have had children.

If you are genuinely autistic (and I'm not convinced you are) then by definition you're mentally a child and your parents are genetically weak.

t. Been in medicine almost 2 decades.

So this depends on what country you're in and what parental custody laws exist. It may be possible to start gathering evidence of things like refusal to do "maintenance tasks" like cooking or cleaning and use that as evidence that she's unfit to get custody. You need to talk to a lawyer because this is a delicate thing and varies by country.

But the simple reality is that your kid growing up in a broken household with a good dad and a psycho/shit mom is not going to work. Psycho mom will be holding the kid hostage to get her way. If you're on your own and the kid is spending half time at one house and half at the other, and one parent is a lot nicer, more friendly, more caring, more involved in life - well, not only is your kid going to like you more, but they're also going to emulate you as they grow older and use the contrasting households to know what NOT to be like. So yeah. I don't think staying together will help anything, but you MUST speak to a lawyer to make sure you get the best outcome in court

posts.com:
>What are the chances that my past actions online will come back to haunt me?
It's 0% if you don't let it.

The way you heal from trauma is that you have to get immediate closure as soon as possible; and as you grow, things are inclined to be action oriented than by situation.

***

To expound mathematically(I apologize for the mathematical gibberish, you can fast forward to the conclusion):
What do you think is the value of a day for a three year old compared to a day for a 45 year old looks like?

a. 1 day for a three year old is (1÷365)÷3 = 0.000913242009132 or around 0.09%

b. 1 day for a 45 year old is (1÷365)÷45 = 0.000060882800609 or only 0.006%

***

Now the above check for a few things:
1. Now if you take both their values and appropriate, a day for three year old is 14.999999999950726 or 15 times more valuable than a day for a 45 year old. Following this, whatever happens on the young person's day increases in magnitude dramatically in comparison to someone who is older: happiness, fear, sadness, hate, bravery, etc.

2. A day can be two days, a week, a month(prolonged events such as a sprain, breaking a leg, depression) - this will alter the calculation significantly which is why closure has to be attained properly. The longer you are held by something, the more valuable it becomes(this applies to happiness as well).

3. This is also the math to "Time heals all things(almost)", the older you get the more insignificant an event will grow. The best thing you can do about something bad that happened is proper closure and simply live a long life.

How normal is psychosis, really?
It seems most of the people on /adv/ will get ideas or feelings unrelated to reality, then they're literally unable to stop, and they don't (or can't) tell that what they're experiencing isn't real.
But in real life that seems quite uncommon.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28072586
Ah, hallucinations. The problem with hallucinations isn't sensory stuff, it's ideas and impulses.
Much like how you can feel bugs crawling on your skin that aren't really there, you can also get beliefs that seem real when they aren't, and desires that seem real when they aren't related to reality either.
It's one thing to hallucinate some random ass demon telling you to die, you'd just ignore the demon since you know it's sus. It's another thing to hallucinate up the impulse to kill yourself, or to believe it's necessary and important for you to kill yourself.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28072663
For instance, this.
If you keep hallucinating that something _does_ make sense, and that you _were_ told that knowledge before you could've known it.
Then it doesn't matter that you were told something different (or told some random gibberish), because you'll mistakenly judge the old gibberish as true, sensible, relevant, and prescient.
And as I understand it, people undergoing psychosis are incapable of noticing that these hallucinatory judgements are hallucinations. If the psychosis tells them that something is important and justified, they can't not believe it.
